instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: boards with voltage fluctuating
threads.message:
i been saving some boards that I'm unable to fix , they all seems to have same problem quarter fin spin , green light ok , 12.6v ok , <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ok , but on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> voltage go back and foward , thinking that maybe something is getting the voltage down ahead , i decide to remove the resistor that enable the s0 lines for example on the first board I'm going to ask for help <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the resistor is <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> once this resistor is removed , <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> go back to normal , 5v steady , then i imagine one of the s0 voltages was guilty maybe a transistor whatever , then i isolate them and i when 1 by one , i finally found that problem was coming from =<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0_REG</SIGNAL> , i remove <CHIP>U7770</CHIP> and the fluctuation stops and all other rails when back to normal , then i imagine , that my problem was somewhere on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> then i locate all the nets , and remove all possible ic , transistors , and caps 1 by one , and resolding <CHIP>U7770</CHIP> to see if stuff when back to normal and no as soon as i resolder <CHIP>U7770</CHIP> voltage start fluctuation again , i also replace <CHIP>U7770</CHIP> and nothing. no short to ground on the line.

the only one i can't remove and test is <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>.

i have different boards with exact same issue a macbook air board 2012 , a 2015 , and this pro 2012 , I'm stuck i think my approach to this problem is incorrect , thank you for your help.

threads.title: boards with voltage fluctuating
threads.message:
Power cycling can be caused by 1000 different things. It just means the CPU doesn't start or there is an issue in the power sequence.

On 3115 boards the clock chip <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> is a common problem when it got liquid damage.
